ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the history of animation, as well as current animation trends and techniques.

Learned about many different types of animations and tools used to create animations. Learned about many famous animation studios and directors, methods they used to create animations. Overview of the history of animation, greater insight into the future of animation.

By taking this course, I learned about the history of animation, different animation principles and techniques, and social/political/economical issues related to animation. I learned how to study scholarly arguments related to animation.
All about animation techniques over time and the leading studios. We watched a lot of the movies we talked about too!
I learned how to think about animation, in terms of form and message. I also learned a lot about the history of animation as well, with a cross-cultural focus.
Broad overview of the history of animation. How to analyze films. Animation is self-referential!
I learned about the history of animation.

The depth to which Professor Gerow is able to dissect topics in cinema is always astonishing and this course is no exception. Professor Gerow teaches you about the history of animation and its techniques while giving you the tools to discuss animation and its effectiveness as a medium on a high level.
I learned a ton about the history of animation and how to view animated films critically.

This course provides a thorough introduction to animated media, including different eras, techniques, countries, and schools of thought. I came away from this course able to watch animation in a more informed way and notice more about it.
Understanding of the history behind animation as well as an understanding of the various types of animation and an understanding of what really is animation on a deeper level.

A comprehensive review of the history of animation (actually only a little Disney!) from its earliest precursors to its newest films. Examples from various cultures around the world. The theory of what constitutes animation, its different kinds, and how form and content work with socio-cultural phenomena. Key thinkers in animation studies  their thoughts, supporting examples, undermining examples, counter-theories, and the professor's own take. How to critically watch animated films, and enjoy them in new ways you might not have thought about earlier.

We learned a lot about the history of animation techniques from around 1910 to the present. We also focused a good deal on animation from different parts of the world along with representational issues in animation, which was nice.

This course gave me a broad understanding of the history and theory of animation. It helped me learn proper terminology to discuss animation studies, as well as develop the necessary writing skills to analyze animated works.
I learned a lot about the history of animation studios, production, and technology. There was also a module focus on east asian animation which I really appreciated.

I gained a good understanding of animation history and the evolution of the industry and art form. I also developed a better concept of what animation is and how it fits within the greater film industry.

I learned about film and animation analysis along with the various types of animation. I gained many insights on themes surrounding the history of animation such as cultural/historical significance and influences based on gender, race, income, etc. along with techniques and theories that helped make animation what it is today.
I learned a lot about the making of animation and its history.
animation techniques, history of animation, how to write a formal film paper
learned about animation, how it works, the different types, and the place of animation in American and other cultures.
I learned how to analyze animation, learned many different films and directors, and gained a more significant appreciation for animation as an art form.
Learned about the history of animation as well as different areas of study in animation such as methods of animation, race and gender, etc.
Animation

I went into this class with just an abstract appreciation of animation, and by the end of the semester, could experience the joy to be able to describe, in depth, just what I loved about it using the concepts and terminology that we acquired. As someone who has to take film classes for their major concentration, I'm excited by how different this class felt from my previous film class. The emphasis on "how" just as much as "why" works are made-- on materials and techniques, animation vs. live action methods of creating diegesis, and the question of what digital methods can bring to the mix -- were all super fascinating. If you're someone who enjoys making art just as much as viewing it, you might find a lot of inspiration here.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was great to see such a wide variety of films in the class, though some of our screenings ran a bit long. On those weeks, lectures + section + films to watch + readings got to be a little much, and it could get hard to parse all of the information & remember it for the final.

Selection of film screenings was super fun and insightful. Professor's lectures were very passionate, resourceful, and well organized. It was very helpful that the lectures were recorded and available to students on Canvas.
Strengths are the content and discussions, as well as the films we watch. The weaknesses are having so many films to watch which can be time consuming during the week.

This course is really interesting because I think most people can relate to the course material. However, There are two lectures, a screening, and a section every week, which is a lot to devote to a gut class...

Strengths: Screenings were fun to attend every week, especially towards the end. Professor Gerow's lectures are interesting. Not totally necessary to do the readings every week because Professor Gerow summarizes the important readings in lecture. Not very much work. 

Weaknesses: Trigger warnings should be required before watching Hentai!! I know the TAs talked to Professor Gerow after that lecture cause everyone was a little caught off guard.

Gerow is a bit of a dry lecturer. He rehashes the readings in lecture but doesn't necessarily make them any clearer. I really enjoyed the one lecture where the TA taught because it was much more clear and concise. I also think he tried to do too much in the lecture course, since there was always an overwhelming amount of readings and other material squashed into one lecture, and he always went over time, which made it difficult to get to my next class.

The strengths of this course are its many different forms of learning: from lecture, to screenings, to section, there are many different modes that are used to the teach the topics at hand. The course did not have many weaknesses, but I think the final exam was quite pointless and could be replaced by a lecture quiz on canvas for each class. This would increase attendance but also assure that concepts were getting across as they are taught rather than asking students to study a semester worth of information that is not very conducive to being memorized for one test.

The lectures were a big strength of the course; they were structured perfectly. I enjoyed the film screenings and section as well. Some of the readings could be a little dense. I also wish we had more practice closely analyzing films before the midterm.

Great class. Was initially scared of the final exam, but its not as bad as it sounds, just pay attention in class and do some reviewing/studying before the exam. I liked the option for a creative project, but it would be nice to have a little bit more info on what is expected with the creative project. The 2 essay/1 essay and 1 creative project is a good amount because it is not overbearing. Most of the movies were really good.  I particularly liked Mulan, Princess Mononoke, On-Gaku, Bobby Bumps puts a Beanery on the Bum, and Urotsukidoji: Legend of the Overfiend.

Strengths - "no fear" attitude for people who have had little or no experience studying film. Shear volume of different animation and examples from early prototypes to classics to experimental and more - we saw lots of great examples in screenings and in class. Professor Gerow brings in the voice of many different animation theorists but doesn't try to indoctrinate students with them (something that is rare but important!) - he provides supporting and counterexamples, evaluates strengths and weaknesses of arguments, posits further stipulations of them. Sections allow for independent thought with a smaller group within the larger lecture. Workload for most of the semester was reasonable  readings (skimmable) for every class, very small animation assignment, short paper. Opportunities to try your own hand at animation.

Weaknesses - time investment for the class is substantial, even if you really enjoy the class. Between two lectures, a mandatory section, and a 2-3 hour screening (+ readings and occasional on-your-own screening), the time does add up. Final assignments were also a bit extra intensive - a short final exam (part of which you need to study almost 100 of the short films we saw) + a short independent animation with a 5-page paper OR a 9-12 page paper on a chosen topic.

Strengths: Great lectures from Prof Gerow, interesting films to watch (some were popular and some were less well-known)
Weaknesses: Course spent a ton of time on early animation, which were among the more dry lectures. Interest definitely picked up as the course went on. Also the final was WAY too focused on memorization of names of films and directors, rather than big ideas in animation, which were what the class focused on.

This course provided a wide range of knowledge and perspectives relating to animation. The readings were almost always relevant to the material covered in class, and the films screened outside of class helped provide examples of the concepts taught by Professor Gerow. The major weakness with this course was the final exam, which leaned heavily on memorization rather than concepts and theory.
Strengths: there is lower weekly workload and the lectures are really engaging. Weaknesses: the TA grading isn't really standardized.

I think the structure of the course provided a really strong timeline of animation history and the major events that informed it. The choice of films was a weak point as I think there were a lot of unnecessary films added to the curriculum.

This class was very entertaining and engaging- I think getting classroom engagement with the material most days of the week (Mon./Wed. lectures, Tuesday screenings and Thursday sections) helped with my understanding of the content. Although I believe the theoretical readings were slightly difficult and drew away from certain lessons. There are also so many films that are watched throughout the course that it was difficult to study for the in-class final exam.

I think this was a very strong course overall. I think one way it could be improved would to have had a smaller writing assignment before the first essay to have a better idea of what was expected from our writing.

strengths- well-organized content, engaging and accessible lectures
weaknesses- I found it a bit odd that the films from women and people of color were assigned over the weekend instead of being screened to the whole class

The films we watched, especially those in the middle and later halves, are really good! The Japanese animation portion was particularly cool. However, I found the lecture to not be particularly engaging. Personally, too, I found the readings to not be conductive to what I was looking for in the course: they had a focus on history, but I was more interested in analysis and interpretation. That, however, might not be a downside for you.
Very cool films and lectures, weakness was that it was a lot of assignments.

Strengths: screenings were very fun, class was engaging, TA's were fantastic
Weaknesses: I cannot think of any

The overall content is very interesting to learn, however at times, the lectures, section, and screenings, coupled with readings take up a lot of times, a better balance of out of class work and in class learning may help the class be more manageable.
Cool class
The course was extremely well-organized and very engaging throughout the semester. The only downside was that the grading was harsher than expected and the exam was quite difficult

Loved the selection of films at nearly all of our screenings! Maybe we could have forgone Final Fantasy and the Ratatouille short, though... 

The non-Disney parts of the syllabus were more interesting to me than the Disney parts, since more of it was unfamiliar. I get that it's important context for American animation, but it seemed that a lot of people would skip these screenings if they've seen those films before. We might have benefitted from a few more films that we're less likely to encounter otherwise.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in the study of and/or the craft of animation.
Yes, Professor Gerow is awesome! If you love watching and analyzing animations, this is a perfect course for you.
Yes, but be prepared to put in work and that this is not just a fun class on animation. There is a lot of studying, historical knowledge and memorizing involved.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in learning more about the theory and history of animation throughout time!
I would definitely recommend this class to someone. It was fascinating to learn about animation's history and watch new films. It definitely strengthened my appreciation of animation as an art form.

I would recommend this course to someone who's interested in animation and it's history! It sometimes felt like more work than I had expected, but it was not overwhelming and was ultimately very interesting and worthwhile.

If a student is looking for a "fun" course on Disney, I would not necessarily recommend it. However, it does have interesting content and provoked me to think more deeply about the films I'm watching. Just know that it has a lot more content that one would expect and the screenings can get long.
Yes! Professor Gerow is a legend and one of the best professors in the film and media studies department.
I would highly recommend this course, though it is not as easy as it first appears.

Yes, the workload isnt bad, the movies are interesting and so is the stuff about animation that you learn. Well-structured. Interesting. A lot of good movies. Weakness: a couple really long screenings. Strength: The professor was understanding about the length of the screenings.

Yes! it's a fascinating topic for people from a variety of academic backgrounds and experiences. You really stretch your idea of what you think animation is. In just a semester you really do learn a lot about many different kinds of animation (not just Disney), and the theories and implications behind many examples.

I would recommend this course to students who are interested in the whole history of animation, not just modern techniques. The course focuses a ton on earlier techniques and animation studios, which is definitely not everyone's cup of tea. There are a few opportunities to make your own animation, but this course does not focus on student-created animation, more the analysis of existing animation.
If you are interested in animation or film studies, I would definitely recommend this course! It's a great introduction to animation as a medium and I found it to be very enjoyable and interesting.

Definitely! This is a great class to add on if you are a different major. It is super interesting and you get to learn a lot of new insights about films that you already know and love from your childhood.
I would recommend. The films are interesting to dissect and the large majority of the films were unknown to me so there was a lot of exposure to new content.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in animation or who wants to learn about various forms of media!
I would recommend this course to another student. I found it both very informative and engaging.
yes! anyone interested in animation and film studies

I would recommend this course to the student that is interested in Animation history first and foremost. Although the papers of the course were analyses of films, I found that teaching was not centered around that.
Yeah! take it. super fun.
Yes I would. I found the staff to be friendly and engaging, and the material of the course to be fascinating.

If you are interested in learning about the history of animation, yes. If you are interested in practicing animation yourself, no. The class is very much a survey of animation history and not a hands on course in terms of learning how to do animation. Overall, you watch a lot of good films, but occasionally the time spent for classes, readings, and screenings can be a bit much.
Yes

If you are very interested in an in-depth exploration of animation and its techniques then yes -- you must also be willing to dedicate substantial time to writing the papers and studying for the final exam. Not a gut!

Yes!! There's so much to like about this class. The units on experimental animation, animated documentary, and animation in East Asia are really wonderful. The screenings for this class were a highlight of my week, every week (except for when we saw Final Fantasy, which was also kind of iconically bad). You should definitely try and attend as often as you can. Lectures were really interesting, and Prof. Gerow does some really interesting close analyses during class. Even if you're not that interested in Disney, you might still like this class. The course covers so much content beyond that and also goes substantially beyond animation production in the US. The assignments are as challenging as you want them to be-- not stressful at all. I personally had a moment, during my first week in this class, where I wasn't sure if I wanted to take this class (didn't love the first screening, which was Who Framed Roger Rabbit). I'm happy I chose to stick with it, since the most interesting parts of the class (IMO) came later on.
